Key Point

For any value of \(\theta\) \[\sin^2\theta+\cos^2\theta\equiv1\]

One way of proving the result in the Key Point is to use the definitions of \(\sin\theta\) and \(\cos\theta\) obtained from the circle of unit radius.

Recall that \(\cos\theta=OQ\), \(\ \sin\theta=OR=QP\). By Pythagorasâ€™ theorem:\((OQ)^2+(QP)^2=(OP)^2=1\)

hence \(\cos^2\theta+\sin^2\theta=1.\)

We have demonstrated the Key Point using an angle \(\theta\) in the first quadrant but the result is true for any \(\theta\) i.e. it is indeed an identity.
